DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reported in Ethnic Intimidation Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A county Republican Party, two GOP assemblymen and their campaign workers have agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a lawsuit accusing them of hiring uniformed guards to intimidate Hispanic voters, a lawyer said. Under the proposed settlement, none of the defendants would admit any wrongdoing, said Darryl Wold, attorney for the Orange County Republican Party. But he said Friday their four insurance companies each would pay $100,000 to the plaintiffs, five Hispanic voters and the Orange County Democratic Party. A federal judge must approve the settlement. The lawsuit had been scheduled for trial Jan. 16 in U.S. District Court. State and federal agencies are still investigating the posting of guards at 20 polling places in predominantly Hispanic voter areas of Santa Ana on Nov. 8, 1988, when Assemblyman Curt Pringle of Garden Grove defeated Democrat Christian ``Rick'' Thierbach by 843 votes for an Assembly seat. The guards carried signs in English and Spanish warning that non-citizens cannot legally vote. Hispanic community leaders complained it was racially motivated intimidation. County GOP officials responded that the guards were there only to monitor and report election fraud. Pringle and another defendant, Assemblyman John R. Lewis of Orange, could not be reached for comment Saturday. Calls placed to their offices rang unanswered, and directory assistance had no home numbers listed for them. Michael G. Balmages, chairman of the county Democratic Party, praised the settlement but said he was sorry the case would not be going to trial. ``The plaintiffs will not get their day in court and the public will be deprived of learning more about the illegal, unconstitutional and highly unethical acts that were committed by the Orange County Republican Party and the campaign of Mr. Pringle,'' he said. ``A million dollars would not compensate for this infringement on our civil rights,'' said Reuben Martinez, treasurer of the county Democratic Party. Joseph Remcho, the plaintiffs' chief attorney, expects the settlement will be approved. He said a court order prevented him from discussing it further before all parties sign it.
